Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2011 12:21PM SeanE wrote: I second what Kaara said about offending your oncologist. Also, MD Anderson has one building dedicated to breast cancer - the Mays Clinic - so it is actually pretty easy to get around.  Occasionally there are procedures where you need to go elsewhere on the campus, but most are centralized there.  My wife was treated there, and received top-notch care.
Posts.Title: MD Anderson Tiger_Blood Tiger_Blood

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2010 12:54PM SeanE wrote: You know, it is heartbreaking to hear, as a caregiver, that only those who have Stage IV cancer really "get it".  I may not know exactly what my wife needs at every particular moment, but I do my best, watch for signals that she may be more tired or more energetic than normal, and guage my activities accordingly.  We have frank discussions about her cancer, and I have asked her straight out whether she feels like I don't understand her.  She tells me no, and I take her word for it. I think there probably are folks who don't understand, or who just don't care.  However, those folks shouldn't be used to paint the whole "healthy" community as insensitive or uncaring.  When we don't understand, as some have stated above, what exactly our loved one needs at a particular moment, that doesn't mean we don't understand the roller-coaster ride of alternating terror, hope, pain, and uncertainty that this horrible disease brings, or that we can't learn to understand as time goes on and communication lines are open. LJ's Mom, I would bet you that your teenage boys probably do have some sense that you don't want to be treated as if you are dying, and yet also need more help sometimes because of your disease, and are probably too young, immature, and inexperienced to know just where to draw that line.  I know that I consciously stop doing things that need to be done sometimes when I see my wife has a burst of energy, so she doesn't feel like she's on a "deathwatch".   I guess the upshot of it is, communication is key, especially with us idiot men, as we don't pick up on the nonverbal clues as well as you more empathic womenfolk do.  I LOVE it when my wife is specific about what she wants, do the best I can to pick up on what she hasn't told me, and hop for the best.  I hope for the best in your family situation as well. Sincerely, Sean E.
Posts.Title: Resentful lukejessesmom Lynn1

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2010 11:04AM SeanE wrote: My wife went through exactly the same thing with her first infusion, but we weren't sure if it was the Zometa, or the Taxol she got with it.  Every subsequent infusion has had almost zero.  From what I understand, the first one is almost always difficult, but subsequent infusions do not give nearly the same problems.
Posts.Title: 1st Zometa infusion-----ARGGGGGH Chickadee cmhartley

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2010 03:19PM SeanE wrote: Everything I've heard indicates tumor markers are not universally reliable.  For some, they seem to track with disease progress, while with others there is no correlation.  That said, I do know that tumor markers often go UP initially when starting chemo - result of the dying cancer cells releasing all that stuff at once.  Here's a quote from the American Cancer Society website: If the tumor marker level in the blood goes down, it is almost always a sign that the treatment is working. On the other hand, if the marker level goes up, then the cancer is not responding and the treatment may need to be changed. (One exception is if the cancer is very sensitive to a certain chemotherapy treatment. In this case, the chemo can cause many cancer cells to die and release large amounts of the marker into the blood, which will cause the level of the tumor marker to rise for a short time.) Hope this helps. Sincerely, Sean E.

Posts.Content: SeanE wrote: My wife Lee Ann had a hard year, but 1 year and less than 1 month later, she has been pronounced NED!  Started as Stage IV IBC with 2 bone mets, one to skull and one to humerus.  She has since been through Taxol chemo, FAC chemo, bilateral MRM, and 51 gray radiation to chest wall and humerus, and is currently in "mop up chemo" with Ixempra. We are SO looking forward to finishing up chemo!  We both feel very fortunate to live in Houston so near to MD Anderson and with insurance that pays for her treatments.  Needless to say, Houston, if it wasn't before, is now our permanent residence. Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2011 03:40PM SeanE wrote: IIIC is about as close as you can get to Stage IV.  Stage IIIC means it has gotten into the lymph nodes in the breast area, but has not gone outside that area.  As long as it is contained in that area, it is NOT considered Stage IV.
Posts.Title: Staging of a breast cancer recurrence Landson08 Helmie

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2010 08:23PM SeanE wrote: My wife also had 2 mets to bone - one on her skull (very tiny, removed by surgery), and one on her humerus (radiated while radiating her chest after BiMRM). She is in treatment at MD Anderson, and part of a trial for Stage IV patients with bone mets only, 3 or fewer lesions, all to be treated with "curative" intent.  They will evaluate these patients over time and determine if they have better odds of survival than other Stage IV's w/o aggressive treatment. Congrats on the clean scans - wonderful news!  My wife and I hope for the same next week when she gets her first scans after completion of her major treatments.

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2010 06:53AM SeanE wrote: Curious as to what your "usual treatment" was back in 2006.  Most folks here in US who are triple-positive are put on TCH chemo - Taxotere, Carboplatin, and Herceptin.  If that wasn't done then, then hopefully you can get it done now - you should at the very least be getting Herceptin.  And Zometa has all but completely replaced Pamidronate as the bisphosphonate of choice, as it is has been shown to be more effective - they are even researching it for potential anti-cancer activity in addition to the bone benefits.

She will be receiving Ixempra once every 3 weeks.  Has anyone here had experience with Ixempra as a single agent (not with Xeloda)?  If so, how bad were the SE's, and was it effective against your breast cancer? Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2010 05:33PM SeanE wrote: Have any of yall looked into or discussed with your doctor the possibility of getting into a study using metronomic chemotherapy?  It looks promising - operates on the premise that the breaks in between each chemo cycle give cancer time to recover and develop resistance.  Metronomic chemo is low dose chemo given daily (NCI described a regimen with low-dose cyclophosphamide given daily, and low-dose methotrexate given twice weekly).  It also operates on the premise of angiogenesis - these particular drugs attack the lining of blood vessels of cancer tumors in particular.  Here's some info on the NCI site: http://www.cancer.gov/ncicancerbulletin/NCI_Cancer_Bulletin_062706/page4 Also, it seems like this therapy would reduce the number of times jumping from drug to drug.  Hope this helps. Sincerely, Sean E.

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2011 03:09PM SeanE wrote: Lori, Lee had a round of mopup chemo that was Ixempra.  Side effect similar to Taxol - neuropathy, fatigue, and blood counts got pretty low.  We didn't finish it, as scans showed all was OK about halfway through. Sincerely, Sean E.

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2010 11:15AM SeanE wrote: Tumor markers are dicey indicators, at best.  For some, they do track with the cancer, but for others, they don't track at all. As your mother is in chemo, there is often an uptick in tumor markers during chemo.  This is because the markers are detected from cancer cells that have died, and hopefully the chemo is killing a lot of them! In any case, though, it is something you should discuss with her doctor.  Sincerely, Sean E.

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2010 08:18AM SeanE wrote: Legally, they cannot ask you, and you are not obligated to tell them, due to the ADA (Americans with Disabilities Act).  Once hired, they cannot fire you because of your condition, either - reasonable accomodations must be made.  I wouldn't mention it anyway, because although you are legally protected from discrimination because of your health, it is very hard to prove, and they could easily hire someone with equal or greater qualifications and simply say they hired the best qualified, without having to say they didn't hire you because of your cancer history.
Posts.Title: I am looking for a job. pattih respin

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2011 02:37PM SeanE wrote: I second Lowrider's suggestion to contact a social worker.  My wife had one assigned to her when she was treated at MDA, and they can be very helpful in navigating the medical bureaucracy.  Also, it is very difficult for the oncologist to give a time frame without full scans.  If he were to base it only on the scans already done and gave a year time frame, but your mother had a brain tumor that reduced that time to 3 months, the oncologist might be held responsible. Submitting to further scans does NOT mean submitting to further treatment.  It just gives a clearer picture of your mother-in-law's health, so whether she chooses to treat or chooses to maintain comfort until her time, the best possible medical choices can be made. I am so sorry she is having to suffer through this horrible disease.  It is my sincere hope that a successful treatment can be found for her, or at least she can be made comfortable for what time is left. Sincerely, Sean E.

Posts.Content: May 14, 2010 11:38AM SeanE wrote: My wife just had a craniotomy, but for bone mets (small 6mm lesion), on her skull, so no brain surgery was involved, just removal of a small piece of her skull, replaced by a titanium mesh.  It was done at the same time as her bilateral mastectomy.  She went home within 24 hours.  It was also on the right parietal.  For actual surgery on the brain, they probably keep you longer more for observation purposes than anything else.  The incision was sealed using staples, so it looked like a zipper on her head, about 6 inches long.  When they were removed a week later, the incision looked great - won't leave much of a scar at all. Best wishes with your craniotomy - hopefully not malignant! Sincerely, Sean E.
